awd_titl_txt: Dynamically Corrected Nonadiabatic Geometric Quantum Logic Gates
awd_abstract_narration:
The prospect of quantum computing has the potential to transform the landscape of our information-based economy.  However, the idea of quantum computing was initially deemed to be a nonstarter because of its reliance on creating blends of exponentially large numbers of possible states of the quantum computer, blends whose delicate balance could easily be ruined by even very small errors.  Quantum computing was rescued by the notion of quantum error correction, which uses a large number of physical bits to encode each logical bit and inserts into each computation a series of periodic measurements, error diagnosis, and subsequent remediation to achieve fault-tolerance.  In order for this to work, though, the fidelity of each operation on a physical qubit has to be above a certain threshold, called the fault-tolerance threshold of the particular encoding scheme. The fault-tolerance threshold is around 99% for surface codes, and around 99.99% for other codes.  While a few experiments have shown one-qubit and two-qubit fidelities above the surface code threshold, in general raising the fidelity remains a major challenge for quantum computing to become a reality. This research addresses that challenge by constructing control protocols that are robust to noise.

The approach taken is to combine the strengths of dynamical decoupling and nonadiabatic geometric gating.  Dynamical decoupling is effective in suppressing low-frequency noise, but tends to exacerbate high-frequency noise.  Nonadiabatic geometric gate operations are effective in suppressing high-frequency noise, but are sensitive to parametric low-frequency noise.  By fusing the two concepts, this research seeks efficient suppression of errors over a broad noise bandwidth without requiring auxiliary energy levels. The major research aims are to find the filter functions of single-qubit nonadiabatic geometric gates that characterize their robustness to noise at all frequencies, to combine with single-qubit dynamical decoupling techniques to improve the filter function at low frequencies, to incorporate physical constraints for experimental implementation, and to use the insight from the single-qubit considerations to extend the new framework to two-qubit entangling operations, attaining a universal set of robust nonadiabatic geometric gates amenable to solid state experiments.  Success will be assessed via the average error rates calculated from numerical simulations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The development of viable quantum technology is largely dependent on learning how to control quantum bits in a noisy environment. The bits need to be controlled with very high precision, and background noise causes "decoherence" -- basically, the quantum computer crashes. Most often, the noise is randomly changing on multiple frequency scales at once, i.e., the noise is broadband. While there has generally been a good deal of progress lately in correcting noise that only changes slowly, our work addresses noise that also has fluctuations around the average at multiple frequency scales, which should enable longer runtimes for the first generation of quantum computers.

In this project, we have investigated a class of operations that were widely thought to be relatively less affected by noise - nonadiabatic geometric operations - and shown that in general one can find a whole family of operations outside that class that nonetheless have the same performance. We then showed how to use a mathematical insight known as dynamical invariants to reverse engineer optimal protection of single quantum bits (qubits) against broadband noise. Along the way, we found that certain aspects of the problem were best handled numerically by using a neural network to describe the control pulses and then optimizing the neural network.

Of course, any useful computing device has much more than a single bit. In many of the devices currently being developed, the interactions between qubits cannot be turned off, so control of the individual qubits does not reduce to the case we studied at first. So, we further developed control pulses that allow complete control over an arbitrarily large array of qubits arranged in a nearly arbitrary geometry, while still protecting against certain types of noise. This method can be used for superconductor or semiconductor-based devices.

Interestingly, we noticed that many of these same quantum control techniques can also be applied to studies of biological molecules. We found a way to improve the usual means of measuring the spectral fingerprint of these molecules, opening the door to an even broader scope of application for the outcomes of our work.


Last Modified: 12/28/2023
Modified by: Jason Kestner
